Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant: Infant feeding practices and maternal work in a context of rapid industrialization

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Adequate nutrition during the first two years of life is essential for proper growth/development and health. However, mothers must deal with competing demands of work and infant feeding, and the trade-offs they make between these demands have the potential to affect their own and their child's life history parameters. India is currently experiencing urbanization and the rise of professional opportunities for women that may alter IYCF practices, which heretofore have included extensive breastfeeding, and these in turn may have important impacts on infant growth and health. This project will investigate infant and young child feeding (IYCF) practices and their relationship with maternal work in urban and rural India. To examine the trade-offs between IYCF practices and maternal economic activities, this study will employ a bio-cultural approach and a life history framework.

This 12-month longitudinal study will examine the relationship between maternal work and the duration of exclusive breastfeeding, the quality and timing of the introduction of complementary foods, and ultimately how these are related to infant growth parameters and health. Furthermore, this study will also include ethnographic information on cultural norms and beliefs regarding IYCF practices, as well as allo-maternal care in a rapidly industrializing country and the relationship to IYCF practices. Examining maternal economic activities and IYCF practices allow for a better understanding of how to quantify the costs and benefits of different feeding strategies to both infants/children (in terms of growth and health) and mothers (in terms of economic and social gains or deficits) and how these vary based on household composition and the different employment opportunities that are available to women in the urban and rural samples.

The data obtained from this study will be important in the context of policy discussions of the constraints imposed by the transition to the urban workforce on time available for breastfeeding and maternity leaves that are shorter than the current breastfeeding recommendations. This project will support the scientific training of a promising graduate student.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Infancy is a period of rapid physical and mental development. Sufficient nutrition during the first two years of life is essential for short-term concerns about infant growth and development, as well as infant health and survival. This critical developmental stage can also have long-term consequences for adult health. While the benefits of breastfeeding are well-documented, breastfeeding and other infant feeding practices do not occur in a vacuum. Therefore, trying to understand what factors influence infant and young child feeding (IYCF) practices is both an important and complex endeavor. One specific example is working mothers who must deal with competing demands of work and infant feeding. Mothers may need the income to pay for resources for the household such as food and housing. However, work often requires mothers to be away from their homes (and thus potentially apart from their children) for a prolonged amount of time. The decisions mothers make may have important impacts on infant growth and health. In such a situation, the benefits of breastfeeding to the infant (growth and health) must be balanced with the costs to the mother (time and energy).

 

The issues presented above are particularly concerning in India, where there are high rates of malnutrition and under-five mortality (risk of dying before the age of five). While the majority of the population lives outside the major urban centers, India is a socially and culturally diverse country with increasing rates of urbanization, in part due to increasing industrialization. These recent changes have given women more opportunities to seek income-generating activities, especially in urban areas, and this has the potential to influence current IYCF practices. However, the transition to the urban workforce can create constraints on time available for breastfeeding. This Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant supported research that examined IYCF practices in both urban and rural areas of Tamil Nadu, India. During this 12-month longitudinal study, information was collected about infant feeding practices, infant growth (height, weight, head circumference, measures of fatness), and maternal economic activities. Through this process, we learned about breastfeeding practices, the types of complementary foods given to infants, and the age that those foods were being introduced. In particular, we were able to compare these practices between mothers who were and were not working, and those living in urban and rural areas. Furthermore, we were able to examine how these feeding practices impact infant growth patterns. This study gave us some insights into the cultural norms/ideals about IYCF practices in this region of India and how the trade-offs between maternal work and infant care are understood within a local context: the value placed on those decisions by both the mother/family and society, and how this influences maternal/familial decision-making regarding the trade-off. The results from this study allow for a discussion of how the women in this population balance their multiple roles and how this varies by location and household composition. Furthermore, the data collected during this study can inform public health policy discussions of the understanding and efficacy of current infant feeding recommendations in this region, as well as policies of concern to working mothers (e.g. maternity leave).
